an5.44:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an5.44:4.2: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the householder Ugga of Vesālī,
an5.44:4.3: where he sat on the indicated seat.
an5.44:4.4: Then Ugga went up to the Buddha,
an5.44:4.5: bowed, sat down to one side,
an5.44:5.1: “Sir, I have heard and learned this directly from the Buddha:
an5.44:5.2: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
an5.44:5.3: My sal flower porridge is agreeable:
an5.44:5.4: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:5.5: So the Buddha accepted it out of compassion.
an5.44:6.1: “Sir, I have heard and learned this directly from the Buddha:
an5.44:6.3: “… My pork with jujube is agreeable:
an5.44:6.4: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:6.5: So the Buddha accepted it out of compassion.
an5.44:7.3: “… My fried vegetable stalks is agreeable:
an5.44:7.4: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:7.5: So the Buddha accepted it out of compassion.
an5.44:8.3: “… My boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces is agreeable:
an5.44:8.4: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:8.5: So the Buddha accepted it out of compassion.
an5.44:9.3: “… My cloths imported from Kāsī are agreeable:
an5.44:9.4: May the Buddha please accept them from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:9.5: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
an5.44:10.3: “… My couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends is agreeable.
an5.44:10.5: this is not proper for the Buddha.
an5.44:10.6: However, this plank of sandalwood is worth over a thousand dollars.
an5.44:10.7: May the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
an5.44:10.8: So the Buddha accepted it out of compassion.
an5.44:10.9: And then the Buddha rejoiced with Ugga with these verses of appreciation:
an5.44:11.1: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable,
an5.44:11.3: food and drink, and various requisites
an5.44:12.1: Knowing the perfected ones to be like a field
an5.44:12.2: for what’s given, offered and not held back,
an5.44:12.3: a good person gives what’s hard to give:
an5.44:12.4: the giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.”
an5.44:13.1: And then the Buddha, having rejoiced with Ugga with these verses of appreciation, got up from his seat and left.
an5.44:14.1: Then after some time Ugga passed away,
an5.44:14.2: and was reborn in a group of mind-made gods.
an5.44:14.3: At that time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an5.44:14.4: Then, late at night, the beautiful god Ugga, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha,
an5.44:14.5: bowed, and stood to one side.
an5.44:14.7: “Ugga, I trust it is all you wished?”
an5.44:14.8: “Sir, it is indeed just as I wished.”
an5.44:14.9: Then the Buddha addressed Ugga in verse:
an5.44:15.1: “The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable,
an5.44:15.2: the giver of the foremost gets the foremost,
an5.44:15.3: the giver of the excellent gets the excellent,
an5.44:15.4: the giver of the best gets the best.
